title: 104_hr125
content: The Act titled "Gun Crime Enforcement and Second Amendment Restoration Act of 1996" aims to protect citizens from armed violent criminals by focusing on arresting, convicting, and incarcerating offenders to prevent them from reoffending quickly. The Attorney General must establish an armed violent criminal apprehension program within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Each US attorney must appoint a prosecutor and create a task force to develop strategies for removing armed violent criminals from the streets. The task force considers severe punishment, laws, resources, and the nature of violent crime. The Attorney General is required to establish an armed violent criminal apprehension program within 180 days. Each US attorney must appoint a prosecutor and create a task force to address violent crime, resources, and limited Federal involvement in prosecution. The Attorney General must also receive reports on defendants charged with violating specific laws and submit information to Congress biannually. The Attorney General must submit biannual reports to Congress on information received and waivers granted under subsection (b). US attorneys can request waivers for subsection (a) requirements, which the Attorney General may grant based on established guidelines considering the number of assistant US attorneys and level of violent crime in the district. The section also defines an armed violent criminal. The section defines an armed violent criminal as a person accused of violating specific sections of the United States Code. It will expire after a 5-year period following the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. REPEAL OF PROHIBITIONS ON SEMIAUTOMATIC ASSAULT WEAPONS AND LARGE CAPACITY AMMUNITION FEEDING DEVICES. Amends various sections of title 18, United States Code, to remove restrictions on certain firearms and ammunition feeding devices. SEC. 5. MANDATORY PRISON TERMS FOR FIREARM POSSESSION DURING FEDERAL CRIMES. Imposes mandatory prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm during a federal crime of violence or drug trafficking. Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code is amended to impose mandatory prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm during a federal crime of violence or drug trafficking. Possession results in 5 years imprisonment, brandishing in 10 years, and discharging with intent to injure in 20 years. In addition to the sentence for a crime of violence or drug trafficking, discharging a firearm with intent to injure another person results in a 20-year imprisonment. For certain types of firearms, the sentence can be increased by 10 or 30 years. Repeat offenses involving firearms during crimes of violence or drug trafficking carry a minimum 20-year imprisonment. The sentencing guidelines for repeat offenses involving firearms during crimes of violence or drug trafficking are as follows: imprisonment for not less than 20 years if a firearm is brandished, 25 years if a firearm is discharged with intent to injure, and life imprisonment if the firearm is a machinegun or destructive device. If a person is convicted of a second offense involving a firearm silencer or muffler, they will be sentenced to life imprisonment. Probation is not allowed for such offenses, and the imprisonment term will not run concurrently with any other term. No release is permitted during the imprisonment term for this offense. The House of Representatives passed the bill on March 22, 1996.
